">\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t1991 - Simba Technologies is founded in Vancouver, British Columbia and Seattle, Washington</li>\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t1992 -&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Microsoft">Microsoft</a>&nbsp;partners with Simba to develop ODBC</li>\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t1993 -&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Microsoft">Microsoft</a>&nbsp;puts Simba technology on 30 million desktops</li>\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t1993 - Digital and Oracle partner with Simba</li>\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t1993 - First to ship complete software development kits for ODBC drivers</li>\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t1994 -&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attachmate" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Attachmate">Attachmate</a>&nbsp;and Liant join with Simba to create legacy data solutions. Simba focuses on connectivity solutions</li>\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t1995 - Pioneers server-based ODBC. ODBC solutions for the&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UNIX" style="text-decoration: underline; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="UNIX">UNI</a></li>\r\n\t\t</ul>\r\n\t</div>\r\n</div>\r\n	2	2011-10-20 18:10:44.44465	2011-10-20 18:10:44.44465	27	\N	latest
22	comparison of the Java programming language with the C++ programming language.	2	<p>\r\n\t&nbsp;</p>\r\n<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\tThis is a&nbsp;<b>comparison of the&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_(programming_language)" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Java (programming language)">Java programming language</a>&nbsp;with the&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C%2B%2B" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="C++">C++ programming language</a></b>.</p>\r\n<table class="toc" id="toc" style="font-size: 12px; border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); background-color: rgb(249, 249, 249); padding-top: 5px; padding-right: 5px; padding-bottom: 5px; padding-left: 5px; ">\r\n\t<tbody>\r\n\t\t<tr>\r\n\t\t\t<td>\r\n\t\t\t\t<div id="toctitle" style="direction: ltr; text-align: center; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t<h2 style="color: black; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; font-weight: bold; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.6em; margin-left: 0px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden; padding-top: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; border-bottom-style: none; width: auto; font-size: 12px; display: inline; border-top-style: none; border-right-style: none; border-left-style: none; border-width: initial; border-color: initial; padding-right: 0px; padding-left: 0px; border-width: initial; border-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\tContents</h2>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t&nbsp;<span class="toctoggle" style="font-size: 11px; ">&nbsp;[<a class="internal" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_Java_and_C%2B%2B#" id="togglelink" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; ">hide</a>]&nbsp;</span></div>\r\n\t\t\t\t<ul style="line-height: 1.5em; list-style-type: none; margin-top: 0.3em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; list-style-image: none; text-align: left; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_Java_and_C%2B%2B#Design_aims" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">1</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Design aims</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_Java_and_C%2B%2B#Language_features" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">2</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Language features</span></a>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<ul style="line-height: 1.5em; list-style-type: none; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 2em; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; list-style-image: none; text-align: left; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-3" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_Java_and_C%2B%2B#Syntax" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">2.1</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Syntax</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-4" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_Java_and_C%2B%2B#Semantics" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">2.2</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Semantics</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-5" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_Java_and_C%2B%2B#Resource_management" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">2.3</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Resource management</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-6" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_Java_and_C%2B%2B#Libraries" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">2.4</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Libraries</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-7" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_Java_and_C%2B%2B#Runtime" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">2.5</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Runtime</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-8" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_Java_and_C%2B%2B#Templates_vs._Generics" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">2.6</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Templates vs. Generics</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-9" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_Java_and_C%2B%2B#Miscellaneous" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">2.7</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Miscellaneous</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t</ul>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t</li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-10" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_Java_and_C%2B%2B#Performance" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">3</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Performance</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-11" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_Java_and_C%2B%2B#Official_standard_and_reference_of_the_language" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">4</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Official standard and reference of the language</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-12" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_Java_and_C%2B%2B#References" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">5</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-13" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_Java_and_C%2B%2B#External_links" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">6</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t</ul>\r\n\t\t\t</td>\r\n\t\t</tr>\r\n\t</tbody>\r\n</table>\r\n<h2 style="color: black; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.6em; margin-left: 0px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden; padding-top: 0.5em; padding-bottom: 0.17em; border-bottom-width: 1px; border-bottom-style: solid; border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); width: auto; font-size: 19px; ">\r\n\t<span class="editsection" style="float: right; margin-left: 5px; font-size: 13px; ">[<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Comparison_of_Java_and_C%2B%2B&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Edit section: Design aims">edit</a>]</span><span class="mw-headline" id="Design_aims">Design aims</span></h2>\r\n<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\tThe differences between the C++ and Java programming languages can be traced to their&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_Heritage" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Virtual Heritage">heritage</a>, as they have different design goals.</p>\r\n<ul style="line-height: 1.5em; list-style-type: square; margin-top: 0.3em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 1.5em; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; list-style-image: url(data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAUAAAANCAMAAABW4lS6AAAAGXRFWHRTb2Z0d2FyZQBBZG9iZSBJbWFnZVJlYWR5ccllPAAAAAZQTFRFAFKM////QIUK9QAAAAJ0Uk5T/wDltzBKAAAAGklEQVR42mJgBAEGokgGBjBGBxBxsBqAAAMACHwALd5r8ygAAAAASUVORK5CYII=); ">\r\n\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t<b>C++</b>&nbsp;was designed for systems and applications programming, extending the&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C_(programming_language)" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="C (programming language)">C programming language</a>. To this&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Procedural_programming" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Procedural programming">procedural programming</a>&nbsp;language designed for efficient execution, C++ has added support for&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Static_typing" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Static typing">statically-typed</a>&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Object-oriented_programming" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Object-oriented programming">object-oriented programming</a>,&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exception_handling" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Exception handling">exception handling</a>,&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RAII" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="RAII">scoped resource management</a>, and&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generic_programming" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Generic programming">generic programming</a>, in particular. It also added a&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C%2B%2B_Standard_Library" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="C++ Standard Library">standard library</a>&nbsp;which includes generic containers and algorithms.</li>\r\n\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t<b>Java</b>&nbsp;was created initially as an interpreter for printing systems but grew to support&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_computing" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Network computing">network computing</a>. Sun Microsystems used it for the basis of their &quot;HotJava&quot; thin client system. It relies on a<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_machine" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Virtual machine">virtual machine</a>&nbsp;to be&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_security" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Computer security">secure</a>&nbsp;and highly&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Porting" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Porting">portable</a>. It is bundled with an extensive library designed to provide a complete abstraction of the underlying platform. Java is a statically-typed object-oriented language that uses a syntax similar to C++, but is not compatible with it. It was designed from scratch with the goal of being easy to use and accessible to a wider audience.</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\tThe different goals in the development of C++ and Java resulted in different principles and design trade-offs between the languages. The differences are as follows&nbsp;:</p>\r\n<table class="wikitable" style="font-size: 13px; margin-top: 1em; margin-right: 1em; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-left: 0px; background-image: initial; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: rgb(249, 249, 249); border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; border-collapse: collapse; color: black; ">\r\n\t<tbody>\r\n\t\t<tr>\r\n\t\t\t<th style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; background-image: initial; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: rgb(242, 242, 242); text-align: center; width: 558px; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tC++</th>\r\n\t\t\t<th style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; background-image: initial; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: rgb(242, 242, 242); text-align: center; width: 558px; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tJava</th>\r\n\t\t</tr>\r\n\t\t<tr>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tCompatible with&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C_(programming_language)" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="C (programming language)">C</a>&nbsp;source code, except for a few&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corner_case" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Corner case">corner cases</a>.</td>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tNo backward compatibility with any previous language. The syntax is, however, strongly influenced by C/C++.</td>\r\n\t\t</tr>\r\n\t\t<tr>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tWrite once compile anywhere (WOCA)</td>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tWrite once run anywhere / everywhere (WORA / WORE)</td>\r\n\t\t</tr>\r\n\t\t<tr>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tAllows&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Procedural_programming" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Procedural programming">procedural programming</a>,&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Functional_programming" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Functional programming">functional programming</a>,&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Object-oriented_programming" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Object-oriented programming">object-oriented programming</a>, and<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template_metaprogramming" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Template metaprogramming">template metaprogramming</a>.</td>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tStrongly encourages an object oriented&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Programming_paradigm" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Programming paradigm">programming paradigm</a>.</td>\r\n\t\t</tr>\r\n\t\t<tr>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tAllows direct calls to native system libraries.</td>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tCall through the&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_Native_Interface" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Java Native Interface">Java Native Interface</a>&nbsp;and recently&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_Native_Access" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Java Native Access">Java Native Access</a></td>\r\n\t\t</tr>\r\n\t\t<tr>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tExposes low-level system facilities.</td>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tRuns in a protected virtual machine.</td>\r\n\t\t</tr>\r\n\t\t<tr>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tOnly provides object types and type names.</td>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tIs&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reflection_(computer_science)" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Reflection (computer science)">reflective</a>, allowing metaprogramming and dynamic code generation at runtime.</td>\r\n\t\t</tr>\r\n\t\t<tr>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tHas multiple binary compatibility standards (commonly Microsoft and Itanium/GNU)</td>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tHas a binary compatibility standard, allowing runtime check of correctness of libraries.</td>\r\n\t\t</tr>\r\n\t\t<tr>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tOptional automated&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bounds_checking" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Bounds checking">bounds checking</a>. (e.g. the&nbsp;<tt style="font-family: monospace, 'Courier New'; ">at()</tt>&nbsp;method in&nbsp;<tt style="font-family: monospace, 'Courier New'; ">vector</tt>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<tt style="font-family: monospace, 'Courier New'; ">string</tt>containers)</td>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tNormally performs bounds checking.&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HotSpot" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="HotSpot">HotSpot</a>&nbsp;can remove bounds checking.</td>\r\n\t\t</tr>\r\n\t\t<tr>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tSupports native unsigned arithmetic.</td>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tNo native support for unsigned arithmetic.</td>\r\n\t\t</tr>\r\n\t\t<tr>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tStandardized minimum limits for all numerical types, but the actual sizes are implementation-defined. Standardized types are available as typedefs (uint8_t, ..., uintptr_t).</td>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tStandardized limits and sizes of all primitive types on all platforms.</td>\r\n\t\t</tr>\r\n\t\t<tr>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tPointers, References, and pass by value are supported</td>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tPrimitive and reference data types always passed by value.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-0" style="line-height: 1em; font-style: normal; "><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_Java_and_C%2B%2B#cite_note-0" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; white-space: nowrap; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></td>\r\n\t\t</tr>\r\n\t\t<tr>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tExplicit memory management, C++11 replace the old standard RAII auto_ptr&lt;T&gt; by unique_ptr&lt;T&gt; and add shared_ptr&lt;T&gt; (smart pointer with reference counter) though third party frameworks exist to provide better garbage collection. Supports destructors.</td>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tAutomatic garbage collection (can be triggered manually). Doesn&#39;t have the concept of<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Destructor_(computer_science)" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Destructor (computer science)">Destructor</a>&nbsp;and usage of&nbsp;<code style="font-family: monospace, 'Courier New'; background-color: rgb(249, 249, 249); ">finalize()</code>&nbsp;is not recommended.</td>\r\n\t\t</tr>\r\n\t\t<tr>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tSupports class, struct, and union and can allocate them on&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_memory_allocation" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Dynamic memory allocation">heap</a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stack-based_memory_allocation" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Stack-based memory allocation">stack</a></td>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tSupports only class and allocates them on the&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_memory_allocation" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Dynamic memory allocation">heap</a>.&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_version_history#Java_SE_6_Update_14" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Java version history">Java SE 6</a>&nbsp;optimizes with&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Escape_analysis" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Escape analysis">escape analysis</a>to allocate some objects on the&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stack-based_memory_allocation" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Stack-based memory allocation">stack</a>.</td>\r\n\t\t</tr>\r\n\t\t<tr>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tAllows explicitly overriding types.</td>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tRigid&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Type_safety" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Type safety">type safety</a>&nbsp;except for widening conversions.&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Object_type_(object-oriented_programming)#Autoboxing" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Object type (object-oriented programming)">Autoboxing</a>/Unboxing added in Java 1.5.</td>\r\n\t\t</tr>\r\n\t\t<tr>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tThe&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C%2B%2B_Standard_Library" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="C++ Standard Library">C++ Standard Library</a>&nbsp;has a much more limited scope and functionality than the Java standard library but includes: Language support, Diagnostics, General Utilities, Strings, Locales, Containers, Algorithms, Iterators, Numerics, Input/Output and Standard C Library. The Boost library offers much more functionality including threads and network I/O. Users must choose from a plethora of (mostly mutually incompatible) third-party libraries for GUI and other functionality.</td>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tThe standard library has grown with each release. By version 1.6 the library included support for locales, logging, containers and iterators, algorithms, GUI programming (but not using the system GUI), graphics, multi-threading, networking, platform security, introspection, dynamic class loading, blocking and non-blocking I/O, and provided interfaces or support classes for<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XML" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="XML">XML</a>,&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XSLT" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="XSLT">XSLT</a>,&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MIDI" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="MIDI">MIDI</a>, database connectivity, naming services (e.g.&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LDAP" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="LDAP">LDAP</a>), cryptography, security services (e.g.&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerberos_(protocol)" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Kerberos (protocol)">Kerberos</a>), print services, and web services. SWT offers an abstraction for platform specific GUIs.</td>\r\n\t\t</tr>\r\n\t\t<tr>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operator_overloading" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Operator overloading">Operator overloading</a>&nbsp;for most operators</td>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tThe meaning of operators is generally immutable, however the + and += operators have been overloaded for Strings.</td>\r\n\t\t</tr>\r\n\t\t<tr>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tFull multiple inheritance, including virtual inheritance.</td>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tSingle inheritance only from classes, multiple from interfaces.</td>\r\n\t\t</tr>\r\n\t\t<tr>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tCompile time Templates</td>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generics_in_Java" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Generics in Java">Generics</a>&nbsp;are used to achieve an analogous effect to C++ templates, however they do not translate from source code to byte code due to the use of&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Type_erasure" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Type erasure">Type Erasure</a>&nbsp;by the compiler.</td>\r\n\t\t</tr>\r\n\t\t<tr>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tFunction pointers, function objects, lambdas (in C++0x) and interfaces</td>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tNo function pointer mechanism. Instead idioms such as Interfaces, Adapters and Listeners are extensively used.</td>\r\n\t\t</tr>\r\n\t\t<tr>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tNo standard inline documentation mechanism. 3rd party software (e.g.&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doxygen" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Doxygen">Doxygen</a>) exists.</td>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Javadoc" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Javadoc">Javadoc</a>&nbsp;standard documentation</td>\r\n\t\t</tr>\r\n\t\t<tr>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t<code style="font-family: monospace, 'Courier New'; background-color: rgb(249, 249, 249); ">const</code>&nbsp;keyword for defining immutable variables and member functions that do not change the object.</td>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t<code style="font-family: monospace, 'Courier New'; background-color: rgb(249, 249, 249); ">final</code>&nbsp;provides a limited version of&nbsp;<code style="font-family: monospace, 'Courier New'; background-color: rgb(249, 249, 249); ">const</code>, equivalent to type*&nbsp;<code style="font-family: monospace, 'Courier New'; background-color: rgb(249, 249, 249); ">const</code>&nbsp;pointers for objects and plain&nbsp;<code style="font-family: monospace, 'Courier New'; background-color: rgb(249, 249, 249); ">const</code>&nbsp;of primitive types only. No&nbsp;<code style="font-family: monospace, 'Courier New'; background-color: rgb(249, 249, 249); ">const</code>&nbsp;member functions, nor any equivalent to&nbsp;<code style="font-family: monospace, 'Courier New'; background-color: rgb(249, 249, 249); ">const</code>type* pointers.</td>\r\n\t\t</tr>\r\n\t\t<tr>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tSupports the&nbsp;<code style="font-family: monospace, 'Courier New'; background-color: rgb(249, 249, 249); ">goto</code>&nbsp;statement.</td>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tSupports labels with loops and statement blocks.</td>\r\n\t\t</tr>\r\n\t\t<tr>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tSource code can be written to be platform independent (can be compiled for&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Windows">Windows</a>,&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BSD" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="BSD">BSD</a>,<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linux" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Linux">Linux</a>,&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mac_OS_X" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Mac OS X">Mac OS X</a>,&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solaris_(operating_system)" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Solaris (operating system)">Solaris</a>&nbsp;etc. without needing modification) and written to take advantage of platform specific features. Is typically compiled into native machine code.</td>\r\n\t\t\t<td style="border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; padding-top: 0.2em; padding-right: 0.2em; padding-bottom: 0.2em; padding-left: 0.2em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tIs compiled into byte code for the&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JVM" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="JVM">JVM</a>. Is dependent on the Java platform but the source code is typically written not to be dependent on&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operating_system" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Operating system">operating system</a>&nbsp;specific features.</td>\r\n\t\t</tr>\r\n\t</tbody>\r\n</table>\r\n<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\tC++ is a powerful language designed for a wide range of programming tasks. The Java language was designed to be simple and easy to learn with a powerful cross-platform library. The Java&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standard_library" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Standard library">standard library</a>&nbsp;is large for a standard library. However, Java does not always provide full access to the features and performance of the platform on which the software runs.</p>\r\n<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\tThe C++ standard libraries provide&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Container_(data_structure)" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Container (data structure)">containers</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Associative_arrays" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Associative arrays">associative arrays</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1" style="line-height: 1em; font-style: normal; "><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_Java_and_C%2B%2B#cite_note-1" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; white-space: nowrap; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup>&nbsp;as well as the Java library inside the&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_Collections_Framework" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Java Collections Framework">Java Collections Framework</a>.</p>\r\n<h2 style="color: black; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.6em; margin-left: 0px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden; padding-top: 0.5em; padding-bottom: 0.17em; border-bottom-width: 1px; border-bottom-style: solid; border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); width: auto; font-size: 19px; ">\r\n\t<span class="editsection" style="float: right; margin-left: 5px; font-size: 13px; ">[<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Comparison_of_Java_and_C%2B%2B&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Edit section: Language features">edit</a>]</span><span class="mw-headline" id="Language_features">Language features</span></h2>\r\n<h3 style="color: black; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; font-weight: bold; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.3em; margin-left: 0px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden; padding-top: 0.5em; padding-bottom: 0.17em; border-bottom-width: initial; border-bottom-style: none; border-bottom-color: initial; width: auto; font-size: 17px; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; ">\r\n\t<span class="editsection" style="float: right; margin-left: 5px; font-size: 13px; ">[<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Comparison_of_Java_and_C%2B%2B&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Edit section: Syntax">edit</a>]</span><span class="mw-headline" id="Syntax">Syntax</span></h3>\r\n<ul style="line-height: 1.5em; list-style-type: square; margin-top: 0.3em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 1.5em; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; list-style-image: url(data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAUAAAANCAMAAABW4lS6AAAAGXRFWHRTb2Z0d2FyZQBBZG9iZSBJbWFnZVJlYWR5ccllPAAAAAZQTFRFAFKM////QIUK9QAAAAJ0Uk5T/wDltzBKAAAAGklEQVR42mJgBAEGokgGBjBGBxBxsBqAAAMACHwALd5r8ygAAAAASUVORK5CYII=); ">\r\n\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\tJava&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syntax" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Syntax">syntax</a>&nbsp;has a&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Context-free_grammar" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Context-free grammar">context-free grammar</a>&nbsp;which can be parsed by a simple&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LALR_parser" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="LALR parser">LALR parser</a>. Parsing C++ is more complicated; for example,&nbsp;<code style="font-family: monospace, 'Courier New'; background-color: rgb(249, 249, 249); ">Foo&lt;1&gt;(3);</code>&nbsp;is a sequence of comparisons if Foo is a variable, but it creates an object if Foo is the name of a class template.</li>\r\n\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\tC++ allows namespace-level constants, variables, and functions. In Java, such entities must belong to some given type, and therefore must be defined inside a type definition - either a class, or an&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interface_(Java)" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Interface (Java)">interface</a>.</li>\r\n\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\tIn C++, objects are values, while in Java they are not. C++ uses&nbsp;<i>value semantics</i>&nbsp;by default, while Java always uses&nbsp;<i>references semantics</i>. To have reference semantics in C++, both pointer or a reference can be used.</li>\r\n\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\tAs a consequence, operator &quot;.&quot; has a different meaning in each of these languages. In C++, it takes an object as the left operand and accesses a member of the object. In Java, it takes a&nbsp;<i>reference</i>&nbsp;to an object as the left operand and access a member of that object (the equivalent operator in C++ is &quot;-&gt;&quot;, which takes a pointer as the left operand).</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n	2	2011-10-20 18:11:58.76243	2011-10-20 18:11:58.76243	73	\N	latest
23	Introduction	2	<p>\r\n\t&nbsp;</p>\r\n<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\tA&nbsp;<b>database</b>&nbsp;is an organized collection of&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Data">data</a>&nbsp;for one or more purposes, usually in digital form. The data are typically organized to model relevant aspects of reality (for example, the availability of rooms in hotels), in a way that supports processes requiring this information (for example, finding a hotel with vacancies). The term &quot;database&quot; refers both to the way its users view it, and to the logical and physical materialization of its data, content, in files,&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_memory" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Computer memory">computer memory</a>, and<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_data_storage" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Computer data storage">computer data storage</a>. This definition is very general, and is independent of the technology used. However, not every collection of data is a database; the term database implies that the data is managed to some level of quality (measured in terms of accuracy, availability, usability, and resilience) and this in turn often implies the use of a general-purpose&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Database_management_system" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Database management system">Database management system</a>&nbsp;(DBMS). A general-purpose DBMS is typically a complex&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_software" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Computer software">software</a>&nbsp;system that meets many usage requirements, and the databases that it maintains are often large and complex. The utilization of databases is now spread to such a wide degree that virtually every technology and product relies on databases and DBMSs for its development and commercialization, or even may have such embedded in it. Also, organizations and companies, from small to large, heavily depend on databases for their operations.</p>\r\n<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\tThe term database is correctly applied to the data and their containing data structures, and not to the DBMS which is a software system used to manage the database. The structure of a database is generally too complex to be handled without its DBMS, and any attempt to do otherwise is very likely to result in database corruption. DBMSs are packaged as&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_software" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Computer software">computer software</a>&nbsp;products: well-known and highly utilized products include the&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oracle_Database" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Oracle Database">Oracle</a>&nbsp;DBMS,&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_SQL_Server" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Microsoft SQL Server">Microsoft SQL Server</a>,&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM_DB2" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="IBM DB2">IBM DB2</a>&nbsp;and the&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_source" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Open source">Open source</a>&nbsp;DBMS&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MySQL" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="MySQL">MySQL</a>. Each such DBMS product currently supports many thousands of databases all over the world. The stored data in a database is not generally&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_portability" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Software portability">portable</a>&nbsp;across different DBMS, but different DBMSs can&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interoperation" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Interoperation">inter-operate</a>&nbsp;to some degree (while each DBMS type controls a database of its own database type) by using&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technical_standard" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Technical standard">standards</a>&nbsp;like&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SQL" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="SQL">SQL</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ODBC" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="ODBC">ODBC</a>&nbsp;to support together a single application. A successful general-purpose DBMS is designed in such a way that it can satisfy as many different applications and application designers and builders as possible. A DBMS also needs to provide effective&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Run_time_(program_lifecycle_phase)" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Run time (program lifecycle phase)">run-time</a>&nbsp;execution to properly support (e.g., in terms of&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IT_Performance_Management" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="IT Performance Management">performance</a>,<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Availability" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Availability">availability</a>, and&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Security" style="text-decoration: none;
