color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Security">security</a>) as many&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/End-user" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="End-user">end-users</a>&nbsp;(the database&#39;s application users) as needed. Sometimes the combination of a database and its respective DBMS is referred to as a&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Database_system" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Database system">Database system</a>&nbsp;(DBS).</p>\r\n<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\tThe design, construction, and maintenance of a complex database requires specialist skills: the staff performing these functions are referred to as database application&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Programmer" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Programmer">programmers</a>&nbsp;(different from the DBMS developers/programmers) and<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Database_administrator" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Database administrator">database administrators</a>. Their tasks are supported by tools provided either as part of the DBMS or as free-standing (stand-alone) software products. These tools include specialized&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Database_language" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Database language">database languages</a>&nbsp;including&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_Definition_Language" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Data Definition Language">data definition languages</a>(DDLs),&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_Manipulation_Language" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Data Manipulation Language">data manipulation languages</a>&nbsp;(DMLs), and&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Query_language" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Query language">query languages</a>. These can be seen as special-purpose&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Programming_language" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Programming language">programming languages</a>, tailored specifically to manipulate databases; sometimes they are provided as extensions of existing programming languages, with added special database commands. Database languages are generally specific to one&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_model" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Data model">data model</a>, and in many cases they are specific to one DBMS type. The most widely supported&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technical_standard" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Technical standard">standard</a>&nbsp;database language is&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SQL" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="SQL">SQL</a>, which has been developed for the&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relational_model" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Relational model">relational data model</a>&nbsp;and combines the roles of DDL, DML, and a query language.</p>\r\n<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\tA way to classify databases involves the type of their contents, for example: bibliographic, document-text, statistical, multimedia objects, etc. Another way is by their application area, for example: Accounting, Music compositions, Movies, Banking, Manufacturing, Insurance, etc. Wikipedia relies on a database of encyclopedic articles and related information.</p>\r\n	3	2011-10-20 18:21:29.459267	2011-10-20 18:21:52.712339	99	\N	old
24	Introduction	2	<p>\r\n\t&nbsp;</p>\r\n<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\tA&nbsp;<b>database</b>&nbsp;is an organized collection of&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Data">data</a>&nbsp;for one or more purposes, usually in digital form. The data are typically organized to model relevant aspects of reality (for example, the availability of rooms in hotels), in a way that supports processes requiring this information (for example, finding a hotel with vacancies). The term &quot;database&quot; refers both to the way its users view it, and to the logical and physical materialization of its data, content, in files,&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_memory" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Computer memory">computer memory</a>, and<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_data_storage" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Computer data storage">computer data storage</a>. This definition is very general, and is independent of the technology used. However, not every collection of data is a database; the term database implies that the data is managed to some level of quality (measured in terms of accuracy, availability, usability, and resilience) and this in turn often implies the use of a general-purpose&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Database_management_system" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Database management system">Database management system</a>&nbsp;(DBMS). A general-purpose DBMS is typically a complex&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_software" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Computer software">software</a>&nbsp;system that meets many usage requirements, and the databases that it maintains are often large and complex. The utilization of databases is now spread to such a wide degree that virtually every technology and product relies on databases and DBMSs for its development and commercialization, or even may have such embedded in it. Also, organizations and companies, from small to large, heavily depend on databases for their operations.</p>\r\n<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\tThe term database is correctly applied to the data and their containing data structures, and not to the DBMS which is a software system used to manage the database. The structure of a database is generally too complex to be handled without its DBMS, and any attempt to do otherwise is very likely to result in database corruption. DBMSs are packaged as&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_software" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Computer software">computer software</a>&nbsp;products: well-known and highly utilized products include the&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oracle_Database" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Oracle Database">Oracle</a>&nbsp;DBMS,&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_SQL_Server" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Microsoft SQL Server">Microsoft SQL Server</a>,&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM_DB2" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="IBM DB2">IBM DB2</a>&nbsp;and the&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_source" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Open source">Open source</a>&nbsp;DBMS&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MySQL" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="MySQL">MySQL</a>. Each such DBMS product currently supports many thousands of databases all over the world. The stored data in a database is not generally&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_portability" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Software portability">portable</a>&nbsp;across different DBMS, but different DBMSs can&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interoperation" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Interoperation">inter-operate</a>&nbsp;to some degree (while each DBMS type controls a database of its own database type) by using&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technical_standard" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Technical standard">standards</a>&nbsp;like&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SQL" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="SQL">SQL</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ODBC" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="ODBC">ODBC</a>&nbsp;to support together a single application. A successful general-purpose DBMS is designed in such a way that it can satisfy as many different applications and application designers and builders as possible. A DBMS also needs to provide effective&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Run_time_(program_lifecycle_phase)" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Run time (program lifecycle phase)">run-time</a>&nbsp;execution to properly support (e.g., in terms of&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IT_Performance_Management" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="IT Performance Management">performance</a>,<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Availability" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Availability">availability</a>, and&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Security" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Security">security</a>) as many&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/End-user" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="End-user">end-users</a>&nbsp;(the database&#39;s application users) as needed. Sometimes the combination of a database and its respective DBMS is referred to as a&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Database_system" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Database system">Database system</a>&nbsp;(DBS).</p>\r\n<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\tThe design, construction, and maintenance of a complex database requires specialist skills: the staff performing these functions are referred to as database application&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Programmer" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Programmer">programmers</a>&nbsp;(different from the DBMS developers/programmers) and<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Database_administrator" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Database administrator">database administrators</a>. Their tasks are supported by tools provided either as part of the DBMS or as free-standing (stand-alone) software products. These tools include specialized&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Database_language" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Database language">database languages</a>&nbsp;including&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_Definition_Language" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Data Definition Language">data definition languages</a>(DDLs),&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_Manipulation_Language" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Data Manipulation Language">data manipulation languages</a>&nbsp;(DMLs), and&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Query_language" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Query language">query languages</a>. These can be seen as special-purpose&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Programming_language" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Programming language">programming languages</a>, tailored specifically to manipulate databases; sometimes they are provided as extensions of existing programming languages, with added special database commands. Database languages are generally specific to one&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_model" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Data model">data model</a>, and in many cases they are specific to one DBMS type. The most widely supported&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technical_standard" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Technical standard">standard</a>&nbsp;database language is&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SQL" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="SQL">SQL</a>, which has been developed for the&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relational_model" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Relational model">relational data model</a>&nbsp;and combines the roles of DDL, DML, and a query language.</p>\r\n<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\tA way to classify databases involves the type of their contents, for example: bibliographic, document-text, statistical, multimedia objects, etc. Another way is by their application area, for example: Accounting, Music compositions, Movies, Banking, Manufacturing, Insurance, etc. Wikipedia relies on a database of encyclopedic articles and related information.</p>\r\n	3	2011-10-20 18:21:52.636296	2011-10-20 18:21:52.876431	99	23	latest
25	Active database	2	<p>\r\n\t&nbsp;</p>\r\n<h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" style="color: black; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.1em; margin-left: 0px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden; padding-top: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; border-bottom-width: 1px; border-bottom-style: solid; border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); width: auto; font-size: 1.6em; line-height: 1.2em; ">\r\n\tActive database</h1>\r\n<div id="bodyContent" style="font-size: 0.8em; position: relative; width: 1393px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\t<div id="siteSub" style="display: inline; font-size: 12px; ">\r\n\t\tFrom Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>\r\n\t<div id="contentSub" style="font-size: 11px; line-height: 1.2em; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 1.4em; margin-left: 1em; color: rgb(125, 125, 125); width: auto; ">\r\n\t\t&nbsp;</div>\r\n\t<div class="mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" lang="en" style="direction: ltr; ">\r\n\t\t<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\t\t\tAn&nbsp;<b>Active Database</b>&nbsp;is a&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Database" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Database">database</a>&nbsp;that includes an event driven architecture (often in the form of&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Event_Condition_Action" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Event Condition Action">ECA rules</a>) which can respond to conditions both inside and outside the database. Possible uses include security monitoring, alerting, statistics gathering and authorization.</p>\r\n\t\t<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\t\t\tMost modern relational databases include active database features in the form of&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Database_trigger" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Database trigger">SQL Triggers</a>.</p>\r\n\t</div>\r\n</div>\r\n	3	2011-10-20 18:23:13.285636	2011-10-20 18:23:13.285636	12	\N	latest
26	Cloud database	2	<p>\r\n\t&nbsp;</p>\r\n<h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" style="color: black; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.1em; margin-left: 0px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden; padding-top: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; border-bottom-width: 1px; border-bottom-style: solid; border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); width: auto; font-size: 1.6em; line-height: 1.2em; ">\r\n\tCloud database</h1>\r\n<div id="bodyContent" style="font-size: 0.8em; position: relative; width: 1393px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\t<div id="siteSub" style="display: inline; font-size: 12px; ">\r\n\t\tFrom Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>\r\n\t<div id="contentSub" style="font-size: 11px; line-height: 1.2em; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 1.4em; margin-left: 1em; color: rgb(125, 125, 125); width: auto; ">\r\n\t\t&nbsp;</div>\r\n\t<div class="mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" lang="en" style="direction: ltr; ">\r\n\t\t<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\t\t\tA&nbsp;<b>cloud database</b>&nbsp;is a database running on&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_Computing" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Cloud Computing">Cloud Computing</a>&nbsp;platform, such as&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amazon_EC2" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Amazon EC2">Amazon EC2</a>,&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GoGrid" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="GoGrid">GoGrid</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rackspace_Cloud" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Rackspace Cloud">Rackspace</a>. There are two common deployment models: Users can run databases on the cloud independently, using a&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_Machine" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Virtual Machine">Virtual Machine</a>&nbsp;image, or they can purchase access to a database service, maintained by a cloud database provider. Of the databases available on the cloud, some are&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SQL" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="SQL">SQL</a>-based and some use a&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NoSQL" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="NoSQL">NoSQL</a>&nbsp;data model.</p>\r\n\t\t<table class="toc" id="toc" style="font-size: 12px; border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); background-color: rgb(249, 249, 249); padding-top: 5px; padding-right: 5px; padding-bottom: 5px; padding-left: 5px; ">\r\n\t\t\t<tbody>\r\n\t\t\t\t<tr>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t<td>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<div id="toctitle" style="direction: ltr; text-align: center; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<h2 style="color: black; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; font-weight: bold; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.6em; margin-left: 0px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden; padding-top: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; border-bottom-style: none; width: auto; font-size: 12px; display: inline; border-top-style: none; border-right-style: none; border-left-style: none; border-width: initial; border-color: initial; padding-right: 0px; padding-left: 0px; border-width: initial; border-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\tContents</h2>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t&nbsp;<span class="toctoggle" style="font-size: 11px; ">&nbsp;[<a class="internal" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_database#" id="togglelink" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; ">hide</a>]&nbsp;</span></div>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<ul style="line-height: 1.5em; list-style-type: none; margin-top: 0.3em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; list-style-image: none; text-align: left; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_database#Deployment_Model" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">1</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Deployment Model</span></a>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<ul style="line-height: 1.5em; list-style-type: none; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 2em; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; list-style-image: none; text-align: left; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-2" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_database#Architecture_and_Common_Characteristics_of_Cloud_Database_Services" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">1.1</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Architecture and Common Characteristics of Cloud Database Services</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</ul>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_database#Data_Model" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">2</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Data Model</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_database#Cloud_Database_Vendors" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">3</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Cloud Database Vendors</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_database#See_Also" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">4</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">See Also</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-6" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_database#References" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">5</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t</ul>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t</td>\r\n\t\t\t\t</tr>\r\n\t\t\t</tbody>\r\n\t\t</table>\r\n\t\t<h2 style="color: black; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.6em; margin-left: 0px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden; padding-top: 0.5em; padding-bottom: 0.17em; border-bottom-width: 1px; border-bottom-style: solid; border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); width: auto; font-size: 19px; ">\r\n\t\t\t<span class="editsection" style="float: right; margin-left: 5px; font-size: 13px; ">[<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Cloud_database&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Edit section: Deployment Model">edit</a>]</span><span class="mw-headline" id="Deployment_Model">Deployment Model</span></h2>\r\n\t\t<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\t\t\tThere are two primary methods to run a database on the cloud:</p>\r\n\t\t<ul style="line-height: 1.5em; list-style-type: square; margin-top: 0.3em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 1.5em; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; list-style-image: url(data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAUAAAANCAMAAABW4lS6AAAAGXRFWHRTb2Z0d2FyZQBBZG9iZSBJbWFnZVJlYWR5ccllPAAAAAZQTFRFAFKM////QIUK9QAAAAJ0Uk5T/wDltzBKAAAAGklEQVR42mJgBAEGokgGBjBGBxBxsBqAAAMACHwALd5r8ygAAAAASUVORK5CYII=); ">\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t<b><a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_Machine" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Virtual Machine">Virtual Machine</a>&nbsp;Image</b>&nbsp;- cloud platforms allow users to purchase virtual machine instances for a limited time. It is possible to run a database on these virtual machines. Users can either upload their own machine image with a database installed on it, or use ready-made machine images that already include an optimized installation of a database. For example,&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oracle" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Oracle">Oracle</a>&nbsp;provides a ready-made machine image with an installation of Oracle Database 11g Enterprise Edition on Amazon EC2.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oracle-aws_0-0" style="line-height: 1em; font-style: normal; "><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_database#cite_note-oracle-aws-0" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; white-space: nowrap; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></li>\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t<b>Database as a Service</b>&nbsp;- some cloud platforms offer options for using a database as a service, without physically launching a virtual machine instance for the database. In this configuration, application owners do not have to install and maintain the database on their own. Instead, the database service provider takes responsibility for installing and maintaining the database, and application owners pay according to their usage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-readwriteweb_1-0" style="line-height: 1em; font-style: normal; "><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_database#cite_note-readwriteweb-1" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; white-space: nowrap; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup>&nbsp;For example, Amazon Web Services provides two database services as part of its cloud offering,&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SimpleDB" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="SimpleDB">SimpleDB</a>&nbsp;which is a NoSQL key-value store, and&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amazon_Relational_Database_Service" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Amazon Relational Database Service">Amazon Relational Database Service</a>&nbsp;which is an SQL-based database service with a MySQL interface.</li>\r\n\t\t</ul>\r\n\t\t<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\t\t\tA third option is managed database hosting on the cloud, where the database is not offered as a service, but the cloud provider hosts the database and manages it on the application owner&#39;s behalf. For example, cloud provider Rackspace offers managed hosting for MySQL databases.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2" style="line-height: 1em; font-style: normal; "><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_database#cite_note-2" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; white-space: nowrap; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\r\n\t\t<h3 style="color: black; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; font-weight: bold; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.3em; margin-left: 0px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden; padding-top: 0.5em; padding-bottom: 0.17em; border-bottom-width: initial; border-bottom-style: none; border-bottom-color: initial; width: auto; font-size: 17px; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; ">\r\n\t\t\t<span class="editsection" style="float: right; margin-left: 5px; font-size: 13px; ">[<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Cloud_database&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Edit section: Architecture and Common Characteristics of Cloud Database Services">edit</a>]</span><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture_and_Common_Characteristics_of_Cloud_Database_Services">Architecture and Common Characteristics of Cloud Database Services</span></h3>\r\n\t\t<ul style="line-height: 1.5em; list-style-type: square; margin-top: 0.3em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 1.5em; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; list-style-image: url(data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAUAAAANCAMAAABW4lS6AAAAGXRFWHRTb2Z0d2FyZQBBZG9iZSBJbWFnZVJlYWR5ccllPAAAAAZQTFRFAFKM////QIUK9QAAAAJ0Uk5T/wDltzBKAAAAGklEQVR42mJgBAEGokgGBjBGBxBxsBqAAAMACHwALd5r8ygAAAAASUVORK5CYII=); ">\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tMost database services offer web-based consoles, which the end user can use to provision and configure database instances. For example, the Amazon Web Services web console enables users to launch database instances, create snapshots (similar to backups) of databases, and monitor database statistics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-3" style="line-height: 1em; font-style: normal; "><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_database#cite_note-3" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; white-space: nowrap; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup></li>\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tDatabase services consist of a database manager component, which controls the underlying database instances using a service API. The service API is exposed to the end user, and permits users to perform maintenance and scaling operations on their database instances. For example, the Amazon Relational Database Service&#39;s service API enables creating a database instance, modifying the resources available to a database instance, deleting a database instance, creating a snapshot (similar to a backup) of a database, and restoring a database from a snapshot.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-4" style="line-height: 1em; font-style: normal; "><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_database#cite_note-4" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; white-space: nowrap; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup></li>\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tDatabase services take care of scalability and high availability of the database. Scalability features differ between vendors - some offer auto-scaling, others enable the user to scale up using an API, but do not scale automatically. There is typically a commitment for a certain level of high availability (e.g. 99.9% or 99.99%).</li>\r\n\t\t</ul>\r\n\t\t<h2 style="color: black; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.6em; margin-left: 0px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden; padding-top: 0.5em; padding-bottom: 0.17em; border-bottom-width: 1px; border-bottom-style: solid; border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); width: auto; font-size: 19px; ">\r\n\t\t\t<span class="editsection" style="float: right; margin-left: 5px; font-size: 13px; ">[<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Cloud_database&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Edit section: Data Model">edit</a>]</span><span class="mw-headline" id="Data_Model">Data Model</span></h2>\r\n\t\t<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\t\t\tIt is also important to differentiate between cloud databases which are relational as opposed to non-relational or NoSQL:</p>\r\n\t\t<ul style="line-height: 1.5em; list-style-type: square; margin-top: 0.3em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 1.5em; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; list-style-image: url(data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAUAAAANCAMAAABW4lS6AAAAGXRFWHRTb2Z0d2FyZQBBZG9iZSBJbWFnZVJlYWR5ccllPAAAAAZQTFRFAFKM////QIUK9QAAAAJ0Uk5T/wDltzBKAAAAGklEQVR42mJgBAEGokgGBjBGBxBxsBqAAAMACHwALd5r8ygAAAAASUVORK5CYII=); ">\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t<b><a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relational_Database" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Relational Database">SQL Databases</a></b>, such as&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oracle_Database" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Oracle Database">Oracle Database</a>,&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_SQL_Server" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Microsoft SQL Server">Microsoft SQL Server</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MySQL" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="MySQL">MySQL</a>, are one type of database which can be run on the cloud (either as a Virtual Machine Image or as a service, depending on the vendor). SQL databases are difficult to scale, meaning they are not natively suited to a cloud environment, although cloud database services based on SQL are attempting to address this challenge.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cnet_5-0" style="line-height: 1em; font-style: normal; "><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_database#cite_note-cnet-5" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; white-space: nowrap; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup></li>\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t<b><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NoSQL" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="NoSQL">NoSQL Databases</a></b>, such as&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apache_Cassandra" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Apache Cassandra">Apache Cassandra</a>,&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CouchDB" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="CouchDB">CouchDB</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MongoDB" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="MongoDB">MongoDB</a>, are another type of database which can run on the cloud. NoSQL databases are built to service heavy read/write loads and are able scale up and down easily<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Agrawal2008_6-0" style="line-height: 1em; font-style: normal; "><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_database#cite_note-Agrawal2008-6" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; white-space: nowrap; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup>, and therefore they are more natively suited to running on the cloud. However, most contemporary applications are built around an SQL data model, so working with NoSQL databases often requires a complete rewrite of application code<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-7" style="line-height: 1em; font-style: normal; "><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_database#cite_note-7" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; white-space: nowrap; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup>.</li>\r\n\t\t</ul>\r\n\t\t<h2 style="color: black; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.6em; margin-left: 0px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden; padding-top: 0.5em; padding-bottom: 0.17em; border-bottom-width: 1px; border-bottom-style: solid; border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); width: auto; font-size: 19px; ">\r\n\t\t\t<span class="editsection" style="float: right; margin-left: 5px; font-size: 13px; ">[<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Cloud_database&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Edit section: Cloud Database Vendors">edit</a>]</span><span class="mw-headline" id="Cloud_Database_Vendors">Cloud Database Vendors</span></h2>\r\n\t\t<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\t\t\tThe following table provides main database vendors with a cloud database offering, organized by Machine Image vs. database as a service deployment, and by SQL vs. NoSQL data model. See the references next to the vendor names for more information.</p>\r\n\t</div>\r\n</div>\r\n	3	2011-10-20 18:24:10.133595	2011-10-20 18:24:10.133595	52	\N	latest
27	Data Warehouse	2	<p>\r\n\t&nbsp;</p>\r\n<h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" style="color: black; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.1em; margin-left: 0px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden; padding-top: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; border-bottom-width: 1px; border-bottom-style: solid; border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); width: auto; font-size: 1.6em; line-height: 1.2em; ">\r\n\tData warehouse</h1>\r\n<div id="bodyContent" style="font-size: 0.8em; position: relative; width: 1393px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\t<div id="siteSub" style="display: inline; font-size: 12px; ">\r\n\t\tFrom Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>\r\n\t<div id="contentSub" style="font-size: 11px; line-height: 1.2em; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 1.4em; margin-left: 1em; color: rgb(125, 125, 125); width: auto; ">\r\n\t\t&nbsp;</div>\r\n\t<div class="mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" lang="en" style="direction: ltr; ">\r\n\t\t<div class="thumb tright" style="clear: right; float: right; margin-bottom: 1.3em; width: auto; background-color: transparent; margin-top: 0.5em; margin-right: 0px; margin-left: 1.4em; ">\r\n\t\t\t<div class="thumbinner" style="min-width: 100px; border-top-width: 1px; border-right-width: 1px; border-bottom-width: 1px; border-left-width: 1px; border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; border-top-color: rgb(204, 204, 204); border-right-color: rgb(204, 204, 204); border-bottom-color: rgb(204, 204, 204); border-left-color: rgb(204, 204, 204); padding-top: 3px !important; padding-right: 3px !important; padding-bottom: 3px !important; padding-left: 3px !important; background-color: rgb(249, 249, 249); font-size: 12px; text-align: center; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden; width: 202px; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t<a class="image" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Data_warehouse_overview.JPG" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><img alt="" class="thumbimage" height="150" src="http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Data_warehouse_overview.JPG/200px-Data_warehouse_overview.JPG" style="border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; border-width: initial; border-color: initial; vertical-align: middle; border-top-width: 1px; border-right-width: 1px; border-bottom-width: 1px; border-left-width: 1px; border-top-color: rgb(204, 204, 204); border-right-color: rgb(204, 204, 204); border-bottom-color: rgb(204, 204, 204); border-left-color: rgb(204, 204, 204); background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255); " width="200" /></a>\r\n\t\t\t\t<div class="thumbcaption" style="text-align: left; border-top-style: none; border-right-style: none; border-bottom-style: none; border-left-style: none; border-width: initial; border-color: initial; line-height: 1.4em; padding-top: 3px !important; padding-right: 3px !important; padding-bottom: 3px !important; padding-left: 3px !important; font-size: 11px; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t<div class="magnify" style="float: right; border-top-style: none !important; border-right-style: none !important; border-bottom-style: none !important; border-left-style: none !important; border-width: initial !important; border-color: initial !important; background-image: none !important; background-attachment: initial !important; background-origin: initial !important; background-clip: initial !important; background-color: initial !important; background-position: initial initial !important; background-repeat: initial initial !important; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<a class="internal" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Data_warehouse_overview.JPG" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none !important; background-attachment: initial !important; background-origin: initial !important; background-clip: initial !important; background-color: initial !important; display: block; border-top-style: none !important; border-right-style: none !important; border-bottom-style: none !important; border-left-style: none !important; border-width: initial !important; border-color: initial !important; background-position: initial initial !important; background-repeat: initial initial !important; " title="Enlarge"><img alt="" height="11" src="http://bits.wikimedia.org/skins-1.18/common/images/magnify-clip.png" style="border-top-style: none !important; border-right-style: none !important; border-bottom-style: none !important; border-left-style: none !important; border-width: initial; border-color: initial; vertical-align: middle; display: block; border-width: initial !important; border-color: initial !important; background-image: none !important; background-attachment: initial !important; background-origin: initial !important; background-clip: initial !important; background-color: initial !important; background-position: initial initial !important; background-repeat: initial initial !important; " width="15" /></a></div>\r\n\t\t\t\t\tData Warehouse Overview</div>\r\n\t\t\t</div>\r\n\t\t</div>\r\n\t\t<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\t\t\tIn&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computing" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Computing">computing</a>, a&nbsp;<b>data warehouse</b>&nbsp;(<b>DW</b>) is a&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Database" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Database">database</a>&nbsp;used for&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reporting" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Reporting">reporting</a>&nbsp;and analysis. The data stored in the warehouse is&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uploading_and_downloading" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Uploading and downloading">uploaded</a>&nbsp;from the operational systems. The data may pass through an<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operational_data_store" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Operational data store">operational data store</a>&nbsp;for additional operations before it is used in the DW for reporting.</p>\r\n\t\t<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\t\t\tA data warehouse maintains its functions in three layers: staging, integration, and access.&nbsp;<i>Staging</i>&nbsp;is used to store raw data for use by developers. The&nbsp;<i>integration</i>&nbsp;layer is used to integrate data and to have a level of abstraction from users. The&nbsp;<i>access</i>&nbsp;layer is for getting data out for users.</p>\r\n\t\t<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\t\t\tThis definition of the data warehouse focuses on data storage. The main source of the data is cleaned, transformed, catalogued and made available for use by managers and other business professionals for&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_mining" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Data mining">data mining</a>,&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OLAP" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="OLAP">online analytical processing</a>, market research and decision support (Marakas &amp; O&#39;Brien 2009). However, the means to retrieve and analyze data, to&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extract,_transform,_load" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Extract, transform, load">extract, transform and load</a>&nbsp;data, and to manage the&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_dictionary" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Data dictionary">data dictionary</a>&nbsp;are also considered essential components of a data warehousing system. Many references to data warehousing use this broader context. Thus, an expanded definition for data warehousing includes&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Business_intelligence_tools" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Business intelligence tools">business intelligence tools</a>, tools to&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extract,_transform,_load" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Extract, transform, load">extract, transform and load</a>&nbsp;data into the repository, and tools to manage and retrieve&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metadata" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Metadata">metadata</a>.</p>\r\n\t\t<table class="toc" id="toc" style="font-size: 12px; border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); background-color: rgb(249, 249, 249); padding-top: 5px; padding-right: 5px; padding-bottom: 5px; padding-left: 5px; ">\r\n\t\t\t<tbody>\r\n\t\t\t\t<tr>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t<td>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<div id="toctitle" style="direction: ltr; text-align: center; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<h2 style="color: black; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; font-weight: bold; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.6em; margin-left: 0px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden; padding-top: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; border-bottom-style: none; width: auto; font-size: 12px; display: inline; border-top-style: none; border-right-style: none; border-left-style: none; border-width: initial; border-color: initial; padding-right: 0px; padding-left: 0px; border-width: initial; border-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\tContents</h2>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t&nbsp;<span class="toctoggle" style="font-size: 11px; ">&nbsp;[<a class="internal" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_warehouse#" id="togglelink" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; ">hide</a>]&nbsp;</span></div>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<ul style="line-height: 1.5em; list-style-type: none; margin-top: 0.3em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; list-style-image: none; text-align: left; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_warehouse#Benefits_of_a_data_warehouse" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">1</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Benefits of a data warehouse</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_warehouse#History" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">2</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">History</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_warehouse#Normalized_versus_dimensional_approach_for_storage_of_data" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">3</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Normalized versus dimensional approach for storage of data</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_warehouse#Top-down_versus_bottom-up_design_methodologies" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">4</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Top-down versus bottom-up design methodologies</span></a>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<ul style="line-height: 1.5em; list-style-type: none; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 2em; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; list-style-image: none; text-align: left; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-5" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_warehouse#Bottom-up_design" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">4.1</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Bottom-up design</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-6" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_warehouse#Top-down_design" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">4.2</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Top-down design</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-7" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_warehouse#Hybrid_design" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">4.3</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Hybrid design</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</ul>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-8" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_warehouse#Data_warehouses_versus_operational_systems" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">5</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Data warehouses versus operational systems</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-9" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_warehouse#Evolution_in_organization_use" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">6</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Evolution in organization use</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-10" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_warehouse#Sample_applications" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">7</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Sample applications</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-11" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_warehouse#Future" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">8</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Future</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-12" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_warehouse#See_also" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">9</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-13" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_warehouse#References" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">10</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-14" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_warehouse#Further_reading" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">11</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Further reading</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-15" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_warehouse#External_links" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">12</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t</ul>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t</td>\r\n\t\t\t\t</tr>\r\n\t\t\t</tbody>\r\n\t\t</table>\r\n\t\t<h2 style="color: black; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.6em; margin-left: 0px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden; padding-top: 0.5em; padding-bottom: 0.17em; border-bottom-width: 1px; border-bottom-style: solid; border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); width: auto; font-size: 19px; ">\r\n\t\t\t<span class="editsection" style="float: right; margin-left: 5px; font-size: 13px; ">[<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Data_warehouse&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Edit section: Benefits of a data warehouse">edit</a>]</span><span class="mw-headline" id="Benefits_of_a_data_warehouse">Benefits of a data warehouse</span></h2>\r\n\t\t<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\t\t\tA data warehouse maintains a copy of information from the source transaction systems. This architectural complexity provides the opportunity to:</p>\r\n\t\t<ul style="line-height: 1.5em; list-style-type: square; margin-top: 0.3em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 1.5em; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; list-style-image: url(data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAUAAAANCAMAAABW4lS6AAAAGXRFWHRTb2Z0d2FyZQBBZG9iZSBJbWFnZVJlYWR5ccllPAAAAAZQTFRFAFKM////QIUK9QAAAAJ0Uk5T/wDltzBKAAAAGklEQVR42mJgBAEGokgGBjBGBxBxsBqAAAMACHwALd5r8ygAAAAASUVORK5CYII=); ">\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tMaintain data history, even if the source transaction systems do not.</li>\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tIntegrate data from multiple source systems, enabling a central view across the enterprise.
