This benefit is always valuable, but particularly so when the organization has grown by merger.</li>\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tImprove data, by providing consistent codes and descriptions, flagging or even fixing bad data.</li>\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tPresent the organization&#39;s information consistently.</li>\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tProvide a single common data model for all data of interest regardless of the data&#39;s source.</li>\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tRestructure the data so that it makes sense to the business users.</li>\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tRestructure the data so that it delivers excellent query performance, even for complex analytic queries, without impacting the&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operational_system" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Operational system">operational systems</a>.</li>\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\tAdd value to operational business applications, notably&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Customer_relationship_management" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Customer relationship management">customer relationship management</a>&nbsp;(CRM) systems.</li>\r\n\t\t</ul>\r\n\t\t<h2 style="color: black; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.6em; margin-left: 0px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden; padding-top: 0.5em; padding-bottom: 0.17em; border-bottom-width: 1px; border-bottom-style: solid; border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); width: auto; font-size: 19px; ">\r\n\t\t\t<span class="editsection" style="float: right; margin-left: 5px; font-size: 13px; ">[<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Data_warehouse&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Edit section: History">edit</a>]</span><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>\r\n\t\t<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\t\t\tThe concept of data warehousing dates back to the late 1980s&nbsp;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-0" style="line-height: 1em; font-style: normal; "><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_warehouse#cite_note-0" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; white-space: nowrap; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup>&nbsp;when IBM researchers Barry Devlin and Paul Murphy developed the &quot;business data warehouse&quot;. In essence, the data warehousing concept was intended to provide an architectural model for the flow of data from operational systems to&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision_support_system" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Decision support system">decision support environments</a>. The concept attempted to address the various problems associated with this flow, mainly the high costs associated with it. In the absence of a data warehousing architecture, an enormous amount of redundancy was required to support multiple decision support environments. In larger corporations it was typical for multiple decision support environments to operate independently. Though each environment served different users, they often required much of the same stored data. The process of gathering, cleaning and integrating data from various sources, usually from long-term existing operational systems (usually referred to as&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legacy_system" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Legacy system">legacy systems</a>), was typically in part replicated for each environment. Moreover, the operational systems were frequently reexamined as new decision support requirements emerged. Often new requirements necessitated gathering, cleaning and integrating new data from &quot;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_mart" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Data mart">data marts</a>&quot; that were tailored for ready access by users.</p>\r\n\t\t<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\t\t\tKey developments in early years of data warehousing were:</p>\r\n\t\t<ul style="line-height: 1.5em; list-style-type: square; margin-top: 0.3em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 1.5em; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; list-style-image: url(data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAUAAAANCAMAAABW4lS6AAAAGXRFWHRTb2Z0d2FyZQBBZG9iZSBJbWFnZVJlYWR5ccllPAAAAAZQTFRFAFKM////QIUK9QAAAAJ0Uk5T/wDltzBKAAAAGklEQVR42mJgBAEGokgGBjBGBxBxsBqAAAMACHwALd5r8ygAAAAASUVORK5CYII=); ">\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t1960s&nbsp;&mdash;&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_Mills" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="General Mills">General Mills</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dartmouth_College" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Dartmouth College">Dartmouth College</a>, in a joint research project, develop the terms&nbsp;<i>dimensions</i>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<i>facts</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kimball16_1-0" style="line-height: 1em; font-style: normal; "><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_warehouse#cite_note-kimball16-1" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; white-space: nowrap; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></li>\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t1970s&nbsp;&mdash;&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ACNielsen" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="ACNielsen">ACNielsen</a>&nbsp;and IRI provide dimensional data marts for retail sales.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kimball16_1-1" style="line-height: 1em; font-style: normal; "><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_warehouse#cite_note-kimball16-1" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; white-space: nowrap; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></li>\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t1970s&nbsp;&mdash;&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Inmon" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Bill Inmon">Bill Inmon</a>&nbsp;begins to define and discuss the term: Data Warehouse</li>\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t1975&nbsp;&mdash;&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sperry_Univac" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Sperry Univac">Sperry Univac</a>&nbsp;Introduce&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MAPPER" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="MAPPER">MAPPER</a>&nbsp;(MAintain, Prepare, and Produce Executive Reports) is a database management and reporting system that includes the world&#39;s first 4GL. It was the first platform specifically designed for building Information Centers (a forerunner of contemporary Enterprise Data Warehousing platforms)</li>\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t1983&nbsp;&mdash;&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Teradata" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Teradata">Teradata</a>&nbsp;introduces a database management system specifically designed for decision support.</li>\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t1983&nbsp;&mdash;&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sperry_Corporation" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Sperry Corporation">Sperry Corporation</a>&nbsp;Martyn Richard Jones defines the Sperry Information Center approach, which whilst not being a true DW in the Inmon sense, did contain many of the characteristics of DW structures and process as defined previously by Inmon, and later by Devlin. First used at the&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trustee_Savings_Bank" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Trustee Savings Bank">TSB England &amp; Wales</a></li>\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t1984&nbsp;&mdash;&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metaphor_Computer_Systems" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Metaphor Computer Systems">Metaphor Computer Systems</a>, founded by&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Liddle" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="David Liddle">David Liddle</a>&nbsp;and Don Massaro, releases Data Interpretation System (DIS). DIS was a hardware/software package and GUI for business users to create a database management and analytic system.</li>\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t1988&nbsp;&mdash; Barry Devlin and Paul Murphy publish the article&nbsp;<i><a class="external text" href="http://www.research.ibm.com/journal/sj/271/ibmsj2701G.pdf" rel="nofollow" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(51, 102, 187); background-image: url(http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/23/Icons-mini-file_acrobat.gif); background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; padding-right: 18px; background-position: 100% 50%; background-repeat: no-repeat no-repeat; ">An architecture for a business and information systems</a></i>&nbsp;in&nbsp;<i>IBM Systems Journal</i>&nbsp;where they introduce the term &quot;business data warehouse&quot;.</li>\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t1990&nbsp;&mdash; Red Brick Systems, founded by&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ralph_Kimball" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Ralph Kimball">Ralph Kimball</a>, introduces Red Brick Warehouse, a database management system specifically for data warehousing.</li>\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t1991&nbsp;&mdash; Prism Solutions, founded by&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Inmon" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Bill Inmon">Bill Inmon</a>, introduces Prism Warehouse Manager, software for developing a data warehouse.</li>\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t1992&nbsp;&mdash;&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Inmon" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Bill Inmon">Bill Inmon</a>&nbsp;publishes the book&nbsp;<i>Building the Data Warehouse</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2" style="line-height: 1em; font-style: normal; "><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_warehouse#cite_note-2" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; white-space: nowrap; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup></li>\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t1995&nbsp;&mdash; The Data Warehousing Institute, a for-profit organization that promotes data warehousing, is founded.</li>\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t1996&nbsp;&mdash;&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ralph_Kimball" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Ralph Kimball">Ralph Kimball</a>&nbsp;publishes the book&nbsp;<i>The Data Warehouse Toolkit</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-3" style="line-height: 1em; font-style: normal; "><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_warehouse#cite_note-3" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; white-space: nowrap; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup></li>\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t2000&nbsp;&mdash;&nbsp;<a class="new" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Daniel_Linstedt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(186, 0, 0); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Daniel Linstedt (page does not exist)">Daniel Linstedt</a>&nbsp;releases the&nbsp;<i>Data Vault</i>, enabling real time auditable Data Warehouses warehouse.</li>\r\n\t\t</ul>\r\n\t</div>\r\n</div>\r\n	3	2011-10-20 18:24:58.84498	2011-10-20 18:24:58.84498	41	\N	latest
28	Distributed database	2	<p>\r\n\t&nbsp;</p>\r\n<h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" style="color: black; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.1em; margin-left: 0px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden; padding-top: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; border-bottom-width: 1px; border-bottom-style: solid; border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); width: auto; font-size: 1.6em; line-height: 1.2em; ">\r\n\tDistributed database</h1>\r\n<p>\r\n\t&nbsp;</p>\r\n<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\tA&nbsp;<b>distributed database</b>&nbsp;is a&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Database" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Database">database</a>&nbsp;in which&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_storage" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Computer storage">storage devices</a>&nbsp;are not all attached to a common&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_processing_unit" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Central processing unit">CPU</a>. It may be stored in multiple&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computers" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Computers">computers</a>&nbsp;located in the same physical location, or may be dispersed over a&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_network" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Computer network">network</a>&nbsp;of interconnected computers.</p>\r\n<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\tCollections of data (e.g. in a database) can be distributed across multiple physical locations. A distributed database can reside on&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_servers" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Network servers">network servers</a>&nbsp;on the&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Internet">Internet</a>, on corporate&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intranets" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Intranets">intranets</a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extranets" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Extranets">extranets</a>, or on other company&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_network" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Computer network">networks</a>. The replication and distribution of databases improves database performance at&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/End-user" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="End-user">end-user</a>&nbsp;worksites.&nbsp;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-0" style="line-height: 1em; font-style: normal; "><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_database#cite_note-0" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; white-space: nowrap; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="line-height: 1em; white-space: nowrap; ">[<i><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Wikipedia:Please clarify"><span title="The text in the vicinity of this tag needs clarification or removal of jargon from December 2010">clarification needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>\r\n<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\tTo ensure that the distributive databases are up to date and current, there are two processes: replication and duplication. Replication involves using specialized software that looks for changes in the distributive database. Once the changes have been identified, the replication process makes all the databases look the same. The replication process can be very complex and time consuming depending on the size and number of the distributive databases. This process can also require a lot of time and computer resources. Duplication on the other hand is not as complicated. It basically identifies one database as a master and then duplicates that database. The duplication process is normally done at a set time after hours. This is to ensure that each distributed location has the same data. In the duplication process, changes to the master database only are allowed. This is to ensure that local data will not be overwritten. Both of the processes can keep the data current in all distributive locations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1" style="line-height: 1em; font-style: normal; "><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_database#cite_note-1" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; white-space: nowrap; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\r\n<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\tBesides distributed database replication and fragmentation, there are many other distributed database design technologies. For example, local autonomy, synchronous and asynchronous distributed database technologies. These technologies&#39; implementation can and does depend on the needs of the business and the sensitivity/confidentiality of the data to be stored in the database, and hence the price the business is willing to spend on ensuring data security, consistency and integrity.</p>\r\n<table class="toc" id="toc" style="font-size: 12px; border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); background-color: rgb(249, 249, 249); padding-top: 5px; padding-right: 5px; padding-bottom: 5px; padding-left: 5px; ">\r\n\t<tbody>\r\n\t\t<tr>\r\n\t\t\t<td>\r\n\t\t\t\t<div id="toctitle" style="direction: ltr; text-align: center; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t<h2 style="color: black; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; font-weight: bold; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">1</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Basic architecture</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_database#Important_considerations" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">2</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Important considerations</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_database#Advantages_of_distributed_databases" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">3</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Advantages of distributed databases</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_database#Disadvantages_of_distributed_databases" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">4</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Disadvantages of distributed databases</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_database#See_also" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">5</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-6" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_database#References" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">6</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t</ul>\r\n\t\t\t</td>\r\n\t\t</tr>\r\n\t</tbody>\r\n</table>\r\n<h2 style="color: black; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.6em; margin-left: 0px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden; padding-top: 0.5em; padding-bottom: 0.17em; border-bottom-width: 1px; border-bottom-style: solid; border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); width: auto; font-size: 19px; ">\r\n\t<span class="editsection" style="float: right; margin-left: 5px; font-size: 13px; ">[<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Distributed_database&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Edit section: Basic architecture">edit</a>]</span><span class="mw-headline" id="Basic_architecture">Basic architecture</span></h2>\r\n<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\tA database User accesses the distributed database through:</p>\r\n<dl style="margin-top: 0.2em; margin-bottom: 0.5em; ">\r\n\t<dt style="font-weight: bold; margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\tLocal applications</dt>\r\n\t<dd style="line-height: 1.5em; margin-left: 1.6em; margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\tapplications which do not require data from other sites.</dd>\r\n\t<dt style="font-weight: bold; margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\tGlobal applications</dt>\r\n\t<dd style="line-height: 1.5em; margin-left: 1.6em; margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\tapplications which do require data from other sites.</dd>\r\n</dl>\r\n<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\tA distributed database does not share main memory or disks.</p>\r\n<h2 style="color: black; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.6em; margin-left: 0px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden; padding-top: 0.5em; padding-bottom: 0.17em; border-bottom-width: 1px; border-bottom-style: solid; border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); width: auto; font-size: 19px; ">\r\n\t<span class="editsection" style="float: right; margin-left: 5px; font-size: 13px; ">[<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Distributed_database&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Edit section: Important considerations">edit</a>]</span><span class="mw-headline" id="Important_considerations">Important considerations</span></h2>\r\n<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\tCare with a distributed database must be taken to ensure the following:</p>\r\n<ul style="line-height: 1.5em; list-style-type: square; margin-top: 0.3em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 1.5em; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; list-style-image: url(data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAUAAAANCAMAAABW4lS6AAAAGXRFWHRTb2Z0d2FyZQBBZG9iZSBJbWFnZVJlYWR5ccllPAAAAAZQTFRFAFKM////QIUK9QAAAAJ0Uk5T/wDltzBKAAAAGklEQVR42mJgBAEGokgGBjBGBxBxsBqAAAMACHwALd5r8ygAAAAASUVORK5CYII=); ">\r\n\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\tThe distribution is transparent &mdash; users must be able to interact with the system as if it were one&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logical_system" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Logical system">logical system</a>. This applies to the system&#39;s performance, and methods of access among other things.</li>\r\n\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\tTransactions are transparent &mdash; each transaction must maintain database integrity across multiple databases. Transactions must also be divided into subtransactions, each subtransaction affecting one database system.</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n<h2 style="color: black; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.6em; margin-left: 0px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden; padding-top: 0.5em; padding-bottom: 0.17em; border-bottom-width: 1px; border-bottom-style: solid; border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); width: auto; font-size: 19px; ">\r\n\t<span class="editsection" style="float: right; margin-left: 5px; font-size: 13px; ">[<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Distributed_database&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Edit section: Advantages of distributed databases">edit</a>]</span><span class="mw-headline" id="Advantages_of_distributed_databases">Advantages of distributed databases</span></h2>\r\n<ul style="line-height: 1.5em; list-style-type: square; margin-top: 0.3em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 1.5em; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; list-style-image: url(data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAUAAAANCAMAAABW4lS6AAAAGXRFWHRTb2Z0d2FyZQBBZG9iZSBJbWFnZVJlYWR5ccllPAAAAAZQTFRFAFKM////QIUK9QAAAAJ0Uk5T/wDltzBKAAAAGklEQVR42mJgBAEGokgGBjBGBxBxsBqAAAMACHwALd5r8ygAAAAASUVORK5CYII=); ">\r\n\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\tManagement of distributed data with different levels of transparency.</li>\r\n\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\tIncrease reliability and availability.</li>\r\n\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\tEasier expansion.</li>\r\n\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\tReflects organizational structure &mdash; database fragments are located in the departments they relate to.</li>\r\n\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\tLocal autonomy &mdash; a department can control the data about them (as they are the ones familiar with it.)</li>\r\n\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\tProtection of valuable data &mdash; if there were ever a catastrophic event such as a fire, all of the data would not be in one place, but distributed in multiple locations.</li>\r\n\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\tImproved performance &mdash; data is located near the site of greatest demand, and the database systems themselves are parallelized, allowing load on the databases to be balanced among servers. (A high load on one module of the database won&#39;t affect other modules of the database in a distributed database.)</li>\r\n\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\tEconomics &mdash; it costs less to create a network of smaller computers with the power of a single large computer.</li>\r\n\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\tModularity &mdash; systems can be modified, added and removed from the distributed database without affecting other modules (systems).</li>\r\n\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\tReliable transactions - Due to replication of database.</li>\r\n\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\tHardware, Operating System, Network, Fragmentation, DBMS, Replication and Location Independence.</li>\r\n\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\tContinuous operation.</li>\r\n\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\tDistributed Query processing.</li>\r\n\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\tDistributed Transaction management.</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\tSingle site failure does not affect performance of system. All transactions follow&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ACID" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="ACID">A.C.I.D.</a>&nbsp;property: a-atomicity, the transaction takes place as whole or not at all; c-consistency, maps one consistent DB state to another; i-isolation, each transaction sees a consistent DB; d-durability, the results of a transaction must survive system failures. The Merge Replication Method used to consolidate the data between databases.</p>\r\n<h2 style="color: black; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.6em; margin-left: 0px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden; padding-top: 0.5em; padding-bottom: 0.17em; border-bottom-width: 1px; border-bottom-style: solid; border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); width: auto; font-size: 19px; ">\r\n\t<span class="editsection" style="float: right; margin-left: 5px; font-size: 13px; ">[<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Distributed_database&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Edit section: Disadvantages of distributed databases">edit</a>]</span><span class="mw-headline" id="Disadvantages_of_distributed_databases">Disadvantages of distributed databases</span></h2>\r\n	3	2011-10-20 18:26:05.334359	2011-10-20 18:26:05.334359	67	\N	latest
29	Behavioral neuroscienc	2	<p>\r\n\t&nbsp;</p>\r\n<h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" style="color: black; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.1em; margin-left: 0px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden; padding-top: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; border-bottom-width: 1px; border-bottom-style: solid; border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); width: auto; font-size: 1.6em; line-height: 1.2em; ">\r\n\tBehavioral neuroscience</h1>\r\n<div id="bodyContent" style="font-size: 0.8em; position: relative; width: 1393px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\t<div id="siteSub" style="display: inline; font-size: 12px; ">\r\n\t\tFrom Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>\r\n\t<div id="contentSub" style="font-size: 11px; line-height: 1.2em; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 1.4em; margin-left: 1em; color: rgb(125, 125, 125); width: auto; ">\r\n\t\t&nbsp;&nbsp;(Redirected from&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Biological_psychology&amp;redirect=no" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; For the journal, see&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_Psychology_(journal)" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; padding-left: 2em; margin-bottom: 0.5em; ">\r\n\t\t\tFor related topics, see&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affective_neuroscience" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Affective neuroscience">Affective neuroscience</a>,&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_neurology" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Behavioral neurology">Behavioral neurology</a>,&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_neuroscience" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none;
