background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Neuropsychology">Neuropsychology</a>, and&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_neuroscience" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Social neuroscience">Social neuroscience</a>.</div>\r\n\t\t<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\t\t\t<b>Behavioral neuroscience</b>, also known as&nbsp;<b>biological psychology</b>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-0" style="line-height: 1em; font-style: normal; "><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_psychology#cite_note-0" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; white-space: nowrap; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup>&nbsp;<b>biopsychology</b>, or&nbsp;<b>psychobiology</b><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-webby_1-0" style="line-height: 1em; font-style: normal; "><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_psychology#cite_note-webby-1" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; white-space: nowrap; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup>&nbsp;is the application of the principles of&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biology" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Biology">biology</a>&nbsp;(in particular&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neurobiology" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Neurobiology">neurobiology</a>), to the study of<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physiological" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Physiological">physiological</a>, genetic, and developmental mechanisms of behavior in&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Human">human</a>&nbsp;and non-human animals. It typically investigates at the level of nerves, neurotransmitters, brain circuitry and the basic biological processes that underlie normal and abnormal behavior. Most typically, experiments in behavioral neuroscience involve non-human animal models (such as rats and mice, and non-human primates) which have implications for better understanding of human pathology and therefore contribute to&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evidence-based_practice" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Evidence-based practice">evidence-based practice</a>.</p>\r\n\t\t<table class="toc" id="toc" style="font-size: 12px; border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); background-color: rgb(249, 249, 249); padding-top: 5px; padding-right: 5px; padding-bottom: 5px; padding-left: 5px; ">\r\n\t\t\t<tbody>\r\n\t\t\t\t<tr>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t<td>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<div id="toctitle" style="direction: ltr; text-align: center; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<h2 style="color: black; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; font-weight: bold; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.6em; margin-left: 0px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden; padding-top: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; border-bottom-style: none; width: auto; font-size: 12px; display: inline; border-top-style: none; border-right-style: none; border-left-style: none; border-width: initial; border-color: initial; padding-right: 0px; padding-left: 0px; border-width: initial; border-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\tContents</h2>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t&nbsp;<span class="toctoggle" style="font-size: 11px; ">&nbsp;[<a class="internal" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_psychology#" id="togglelink" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; ">hide</a>]&nbsp;</span></div>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<ul style="line-height: 1.5em; list-style-type: none; margin-top: 0.3em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; list-style-image: none; text-align: left; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_psychology#History" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">1</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">History</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_psychology#Relationship_to_other_fields_of_psychology_and_biology" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">2</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Relationship to other fields of psychology and biology</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_psychology#Research_methods" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">3</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Research methods</span></a>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<ul style="line-height: 1.5em; list-style-type: none; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 2em; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; list-style-image: none; text-align: left; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-4" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_psychology#Disabling_or_decreasing_neural_function" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">3.1</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Disabling or decreasing neural function</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-5" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_psychology#Enhancing_neural_function" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">3.2</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Enhancing neural function</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-6" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_psychology#Measuring_neural_activity" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">3.3</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Measuring neural activity</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-7" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_psychology#Genetic_manipulations" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">3.4</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Genetic manipulations</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-8" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_psychology#Limitations_and_advantages" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">3.5</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Limitations and advantages</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</ul>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-9" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_psychology#Topic_areas_in_behavioral_neuroscience" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">4</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Topic areas in behavioral neuroscience</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-10" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_psychology#Nobel_Laureates" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">5</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">Nobel Laureates</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-11" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_psychology#See_also" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">6</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-12" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_psychology#References" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">7</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-13" style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_psychology#External_links" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span class="tocnumber">8</span>&nbsp;<span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t</ul>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t</td>\r\n\t\t\t\t</tr>\r\n\t\t\t</tbody>\r\n\t\t</table>\r\n\t\t<h2 style="color: black; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.6em; margin-left: 0px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden; padding-top: 0.5em; padding-bottom: 0.17em; border-bottom-width: 1px; border-bottom-style: solid; border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); width: auto; font-size: 19px; ">\r\n\t\t\t<span class="editsection" style="float: right; margin-left: 5px; font-size: 13px; ">[<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Behavioral_neuroscience&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Edit section: History">edit</a>]</span><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>\r\n\t\t<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\t\t\tBehavioral neuroscience as a scientific discipline emerged from a variety of scientific and philosophical traditions in the 18th and 19th centuries. In philosophy, men like&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ren%C3%A9_Descartes" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="René Descartes">Ren&eacute; Descartes</a>&nbsp;proposed physical models to explain animal and human behavior. Descartes, for example, suggested that the&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pineal_gland" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Pineal gland">pineal gland</a>, a midline unpaired structure in the brain of many organisms, was the point of contact between mind and body. Descartes also elaborated on a theory in which the&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pneumatics" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Pneumatics">pneumatics</a>&nbsp;of bodily fluids could explain&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reflexes" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Reflexes">reflexes</a>&nbsp;and other motor behavior. This theory was inspired by moving statues in a garden in Paris.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Carlson_2-0" style="line-height: 1em; font-style: normal; "><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_psychology#cite_note-Carlson-2" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; white-space: nowrap; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\r\n\t\t<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\t\t\tOther philosophers also helped give birth to&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychology" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Psychology">psychology</a>. One of the earliest textbooks in the new field,&nbsp;<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Principles_of_Psychology" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="The Principles of Psychology">The Principles of Psychology</a></i>&nbsp;by&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_James" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="William James">William James</a>&nbsp;(1890), argues that the scientific study of psychology should be grounded in an understanding of biology:</p>\r\n\t\t<table class="cquote" style="font-size: 13px; margin-top: auto; margin-right: auto; margin-bottom: auto; margin-left: auto; border-collapse: collapse; border-top-style: none; border-right-style: none; border-bottom-style: none; border-left-style: none; background-color: transparent; width: auto; ">\r\n\t\t\t<tbody>\r\n\t\t\t\t<tr>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t<td style="color: rgb(178, 183, 242); font-size: 35px; font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif; font-weight: bold; text-align: left; padding-top: 10px; padding-right: 10px; padding-bottom: 10px; padding-left: 10px; " valign="top" width="20">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t&ldquo;</td>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t<td style="padding-top: 4px; padding-right: 10px; padding-bottom: 4px; padding-left: 10px; " valign="top">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\tBodily experiences, therefore, and more particularly brain-experiences, must take a place amongst those conditions of the mental life of which Psychology need take account. The spiritualist and the associationist must both be &#39;cerebralists,&#39; to the extent at least of admitting that certain peculiarities in the way of working of their own favorite principles are explicable only by the fact that the brain laws are a codeterminant of their result.\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\tOur first conclusion, then, is that a certain amount of brain-physiology must be presupposed or included in Psychology.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-James_3-0" style="line-height: 1em; font-style: normal; "><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_psychology#cite_note-James-3" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; white-space: nowrap; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t</td>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t<td style="color: rgb(178, 183, 242); font-size: 35px; font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif; font-weight: bold; text-align: right; padding-top: 10px; padding-right: 10px; padding-bottom: 10px; padding-left: 10px; " valign="bottom" width="20">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t&rdquo;</td>\r\n\t\t\t\t</tr>\r\n\t\t\t</tbody>\r\n\t\t</table>\r\n\t\t<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\t\t\tJames, like many early psychologists, had considerable training in physiology. The emergence of both psychology and behavioral neuroscience as legitimate sciences can be traced from the emergence of physiology from&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anatomy" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Anatomy">anatomy</a>, particularly&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neuroanatomy" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Neuroanatomy">neuroanatomy</a>. Physiologists conducted experiments on living organisms, a practice that was distrusted by the dominant anatomists of the 18th and 19th centuries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Shepherd_4-0" style="line-height: 1em; font-style: normal; "><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_psychology#cite_note-Shepherd-4" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; white-space: nowrap; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup>&nbsp;The influential work of&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Claude_Bernard" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Claude Bernard">Claude Bernard</a>,&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Bell" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Charles Bell">Charles Bell</a>, and&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Harvey" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="William Harvey">William Harvey</a>&nbsp;helped to convince the scientific community that reliable data could be obtained from living subjects.</p>\r\n\t\t<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\t\t\tThe term &quot;psychobiology&quot; has been used in a variety of contexts,emphasizing the importance of biology, which is the discipline that studies organic, neural and cellular modifications in behavior, plasticity in neuroscience, and biological deceases in all aspects, in addition, biology focuses and analyzes behavior and all the subjects it is concerned about, from a scientific point of view. In this context, psychology helps as a complementary, but important discipline in the neurobiological sciences. The role of psychology in this questions is that of a social tool that backs up the main or strongest biological science. The term &quot;psychobiology&quot; was first used in its modern sense by Knight Dunlap in his book&nbsp;<i>An Outline of Psychobiology (1914)</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dewsbury_5-0" style="line-height: 1em; font-style: normal; "><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_psychology#cite_note-Dewsbury-5" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; white-space: nowrap; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup>&nbsp;Dunlap also was the founder and editor-in-chief of the journal&nbsp;<i>Psychobiology</i>. In the announcement of that journal, Dunlap writes that the journal will publish research &quot;...bearing on the interconnection of mental and physiological functions&quot;, which describes the field of behavioral neuroscience even in its modern sense.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dewsbury_5-1" style="line-height: 1em; font-style: normal; "><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_psychology#cite_note-Dewsbury-5" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; white-space: nowrap; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\r\n\t\t<h2 style="color: black; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.6em; margin-left: 0px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden; padding-top: 0.5em; padding-bottom: 0.17em; border-bottom-width: 1px; border-bottom-style: solid; border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); width: auto; font-size: 19px; ">\r\n\t\t\t<span class="editsection" style="float: right; margin-left: 5px; font-size: 13px; ">[<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Behavioral_neuroscience&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Edit section: Relationship to other fields of psychology and biology">edit</a>]</span><span class="mw-headline" id="Relationship_to_other_fields_of_psychology_and_biology">Relationship to other fields of psychology and biology</span></h2>\r\n\t\t<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\t\t\tIn many cases, humans may serve as experimental subjects in behavioral neuroscience experiments; however, a great deal of the experimental literature in behavioral neuroscience comes from the study of non-human species, most frequently rats, mice, and monkeys. As a result, a critical assumption in behavioral neuroscience is that organisms share biological and behavioral similarities, enough to permit extrapolations across species. This allies behavioral neuroscience closely with&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparative_psychology" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Comparative psychology">comparative psychology</a>,&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_psychology" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Evolutionary psychology">evolutionary psychology</a>,&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_biology" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Evolutionary biology">evolutionary biology</a>, and&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neurobiology" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Neurobiology">neurobiology</a>. Behavioral neuroscience also has paradigmatic and methodological similarities to&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neuropsychology" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Neuropsychology">neuropsychology</a>, which relies heavily on the study of the behavior of humans with nervous system dysfunction (i.e., a non-experimentally based biological manipulation).</p>\r\n\t\t<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\t\t\tSynonyms for behavioral neuroscience include biopsychology and psychobiology.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-6" style="line-height: 1em; font-style: normal; "><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_psychology#cite_note-6" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; white-space: nowrap; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup>&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physiological_psychology" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Physiological psychology">Physiological psychology</a>&nbsp;is another term often used synonymously with behavioral neuroscience, though authors would make physiological psychology a subfield of behavioral neuroscience, with an appropriately narrow definition.</p>\r\n\t\t<h2 style="color: black; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.6em; margin-left: 0px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden; padding-top: 0.5em; padding-bottom: 0.17em; border-bottom-width: 1px; border-bottom-style: solid; border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); width: auto; font-size: 19px; ">\r\n\t\t\t<span class="editsection" style="float: right; margin-left: 5px; font-size: 13px; ">[<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Behavioral_neuroscience&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Edit section: Research methods">edit</a>]</span><span class="mw-headline" id="Research_methods">Research methods</span></h2>\r\n\t\t<p style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\t\t\tThe distinguishing characteristic of a behavioral neuroscience experiment is that either the&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Independent_variable" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Independent variable">independent variable</a>&nbsp;of the experiment is biological, or some&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dependent_variable" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Dependent variable">dependent variable</a>&nbsp;is biological. In other words, the&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nervous_system" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Nervous system">nervous system</a>&nbsp;of the organism under study is permanently or temporarily altered, or some aspect of the nervous system is measured (usually to be related to a behavioral variable).</p>\r\n\t\t<h3 style="color: black; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; font-weight: bold; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.3em; margin-left: 0px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden; padding-top: 0.5em; padding-bottom: 0.17em; border-bottom-width: initial; border-bottom-style: none; border-bottom-color: initial; width: auto; font-size: 17px; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; ">\r\n\t\t\t<span class="editsection" style="float: right; margin-left: 5px; font-size: 13px; ">[<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Behavioral_neuroscience&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Edit section: Disabling or decreasing neural function">edit</a>]</span><span class="mw-headline" id="Disabling_or_decreasing_neural_function">Disabling or decreasing neural function</span></h3>\r\n\t\t<ul style="line-height: 1.5em; list-style-type: square; margin-top: 0.3em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 1.5em; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; list-style-image: url(data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAUAAAANCAMAAABW4lS6AAAAGXRFWHRTb2Z0d2FyZQBBZG9iZSBJbWFnZVJlYWR5ccllPAAAAAZQTFRFAFKM////QIUK9QAAAAJ0Uk5T/wDltzBKAAAAGklEQVR42mJgBAEGokgGBjBGBxBxsBqAAAMACHwALd5r8ygAAAAASUVORK5CYII=); ">\r\n\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t<b><a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lesions" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Lesions">Lesions</a></b>&nbsp;- A classic method in which a brain-region of interest is destroyed or stimulated to observe any resulting changes such as degraded or enhanced performance on some behavioral measure. Lesions can be placed with relatively high accuracy thanks to a variety of brain &#39;atlases&#39; which provide a map of brain regions in 3-dimensional&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stereotactic_surgery" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Stereotactic surgery">stereotactic coordinates</a>.\r\n\t\t\t\t<ul style="line-height: 1.5em; list-style-type: square; margin-top: 0.3em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 1.5em; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; list-style-image: url(data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAUAAAANCAMAAABW4lS6AAAAGXRFWHRTb2Z0d2FyZQBBZG9iZSBJbWFnZVJlYWR5ccllPAAAAAZQTFRFAFKM////QIUK9QAAAAJ0Uk5T/wDltzBKAAAAGklEQVR42mJgBAEGokgGBjBGBxBxsBqAAAMACHwALd5r8ygAAAAASUVORK5CYII=); ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<b>Surgical lesions</b>&nbsp;- Neural tissue is destroyed by removing it surgically.</li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<b>Electrolytic lesions</b>&nbsp;- Neural tissue is destroyed through the application of electrical shock trauma.</li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<b>Chemical lesions</b>&nbsp;- Neural tissue is destroyed by the infusion of a&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neurotoxin" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Neurotoxin">neurotoxin</a>.</li>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t<li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<b>Temporary lesions</b>&nbsp;- Neural tissue is temporarily disabled&nbsp;</li>\r\n\t\t\t\t</ul>\r\n\t\t\t</li>\r\n\t\t</ul>\r\n\t</div>\r\n</div>\r\n	4	2011-10-20 18:35:22.151393	2011-10-20 18:36:57.717118	32	\N	old
30	Behavioral neuroscienc	2	<h3>\r\n\t&nbsp;</h3>\r\n<h3 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" style="color: black; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.1em; margin-left: 0px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden; padding-top: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; border-bottom-width: 1px; border-bottom-style: solid; border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); width: auto; font-size: 1.6em; line-height: 1.2em; ">\r\n\t<strong>Behavioral neuroscience</strong></h3>\r\n<div id="bodyContent" style="font-size: 0.8em; position: relative; width: 1393px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\t<h3 id="siteSub" style="display: inline; font-size: 12px; ">\r\n\t\t<strong>From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</strong></h3>\r\n\t<h3 id="contentSub" style="font-size: 11px; white-space: nowrap; background-position: 0% 0%; background-repeat: no-repeat no-repeat; "><span title="Edit this template">e</span></a></span></span></strong></h3>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t</td>\r\n\t\t\t\t</tr>\r\n\t\t\t</tbody>\r\n\t\t</table>\r\n\t\t<h3 class="dablink" style="font-style: italic; padding-left: 2em; margin-bottom: 0.5em; ">\r\n\t\t\t<strong>&quot;Biological psychology&quot; redirects here. For the journal, see&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_Psychology_(journal)" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Biological Psychology (journal)">Biological Psychology (journal)</a>.</strong></h3>\r\n\t\t<h3 class="dablink" style="font-style: italic; padding-left: 2em; margin-bottom: 0.5em; ">\r\n\t\t\t<strong>For related topics, see&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affective_neuroscience" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Affective neuroscience">Affective neuroscience</a>,&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_neurology" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Behavioral neurology">Behavioral neurology</a>,&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_neuroscience" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Cognitive neuroscience">Cognitive neuroscience</a>,&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neuropsychiatry" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Neuropsychiatry">Neuropsychiatry</a>,&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neuropsychology" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Neuropsychology">Neuropsychology</a>, and&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_neuroscience" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Social neuroscience">Social neuroscience</a>.</strong></h3>\r\n\t\t<h3 style="margin-top: 0.4em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px; line-height: 1.5em; ">\r\n\t\t\t<strong>Behavioral neuroscience, also known as&nbsp;biological psychology,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-0" style="line-height: 1em; font-style: normal; "><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_psychology#cite_note-0" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; white-space: nowrap; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup>&nbsp;biopsychology, or&nbsp;psychobiology<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-webby_1-0" style="line-height: 1em; font-style: normal; "><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_psychology#cite_note-webby-1" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; white-space: nowrap; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; "><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup>&nbsp;is the application of the principles of&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biology" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Biology">biology</a>&nbsp;(in particular&nbsp;<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neurobiology" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Neurobiology">neurobiology</a>), to the study of<a class="mw-redirect" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physiological" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Physiological">physiological</a>, genetic, and developmental mechanisms of behavior in&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Human">human</a>&nbsp;and non-human animals. It typically investigates at the level of nerves, neurotransmitters, brain circuitry and the basic biological processes that underlie normal and abnormal behavior. Most typically, experiments in behavioral neuroscience involve non-human animal models (such as rats and mice, and non-human primates) which have implications for better understanding of human pathology and therefore contribute to&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evidence-based_practice" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(6, 69, 173); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; background-position: initial initial; background-repeat: initial initial; " title="Evidence-based practice">evidence-based practice</a>.</strong></h3>\r\n\t\t<table class="toc" id="toc" style="font-size: 12px; border-top-style: solid; border-right-style: solid; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left-style: solid; border-top-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-right-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-bottom-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); border-left-color: rgb(170, 170, 170); background-color: rgb(249, 249, 249); padding-top: 5px; padding-right: 5px; padding-bottom: 5px; padding-left: 5px; ">\r\n\t\t\t<tbody>\r\n\t\t\t\t<tr>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t<td>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<div id="toctitle" style="direction: ltr; text-align: center; ">\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<h3 style="color: black; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-color: initial; font-weight: bold; margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.6em; margin-left: 0px; overflow-x: hidden; overflow-y: hidden; padding-top: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; border-bottom-style: none; width: auto; font-size: 12px; ">hide</a>]&nbsp;</span></strong></h3>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t</div>\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<ul style="line-height: 1.5em; list-style-type: none; margin-top: 0.3em; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.5em; margin-left: 0px;
